The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.
div.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 1 May to 31 October.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Monday until 4 June, and then every Tuesday. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.

The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. Combined fare to London by sea and traid de luxe via Brindisi or via Marseilles £19.4.11.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez weekly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for Port Sudan and Suakin direct returning from Suakin every Wednesday noon. Every Monday at 6 p.m. a steamer leaves for Jeddah continuing every other week for Suakin, Massowah, Hodeidah, Aden. Intermediate Steamers do not proceed at Jeddah but call at Tor (for Sinai) El Wedj and Yambo as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company’s Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: Austrian Lloyd’s Steam Navigation
div.p: Alexandria-Brindisi-Trieste (Venice).

Weekly Express Mail Service. Steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4 p.m. arrive at Brindisi, Tuesday 5 a.m. in time for express to Milan, Lucerne, Paris, Vienna, Berlin, and London, leaving Brindisi 7 a.m. Arrival Venice every Wednesday about 8:30 a.m. in time for express to Switzerland, Paris and London leaving Venice 2 p.m. and 11:20 p.m. Arrival Trieste every Wednesday about 3 p.m. in connection with Train de Luxe Trieste-Vienna-Ostende. Passengers reach London every Friday 4.50 p.m. Passengers from Cairo will find special through carriages and luggage-van attached every Saturday attached to Express leaving Cairo 9:30 a.m. and are conveyed directly to Quay alongside steamer.

div.head: Icilma.
div.p: ARABIC FOR "FLOWS THE WATER.”

Icilma Fluor Cream is the only cream that contains no grease nor oil. Deliciously scented it cleanses the pores of the skin as nothing else can do, makes it pearly white, gives life to the tissues, elasticity to the muscles, and a deliciously cool feeling to the skin.

Its unique properties are due to Icilma Natural Water so that it may well be called Nature’s Skin Food and the skin requires nothing else to give it the necessary vitality, to preserve it from sunburn, heat, cold or the effects of hard water, to prevent and cure the minor irritations due to overheated blood, and to preserve the youthful fresh look to which hot climates are so fatal.
Invaluable for immediately curing mosquito and insect bites and for greatly preventing them.
Depot for Egypt : J. McGregor, Chemist.
Alexandria, Cairo, Ibrahimieh, Luxor, Icilma Co. Ltd., 142, Gray’s Inn Road, London, W. C.

div.head: THE GOVERNMENT AND THE ARMY.
div.p: Soldiers cannot but regard as ominous the signs and tokens of the forthcoming pronouncement of the Government, and they deplore the disastrous policy which seems t have been foreshadowed byMr. Haldane's latest utterances. Soldiers who study the question at issue will entertain no doubt whatever as to what are the requirements of the military situation. Statesmen who know the history of the Army will not contemplate any real diminution of it. Those who saw the dangers behind the Conference of Algeoiras who have had to strengthen the garrison of Egypt foolishly reduced, who were prepared to run the risk of a war with the Turk, who are confronted with the native danger in South Africa, will stultify themselves if they speak of it. After the great war, the exhaustion of the nations led to a reduction of armaments, but there were some prescient men who foresaw the danger. The Duke of Wellingtonhad vainly urged successive Governments to organise the Army on a new footing, and Lord Palmerston declared to the Cabinet in 1846 that the Empire existed only by the sufferances and forbearance of other Powers. It was the opinion of Sir John Burgoyne that the very object of armed forces was being gradually lost eight of, the scale of armaments being measured by peace requirements. Notwithstanding the zealous efforts of that good soldier, Lord Hardinge the British Army left for the Crimea still armed with the old smooth bore, while its general state of unpreparedness is recorded in all our histories. It had been stated by Mr. Cobden and others that the addition of 25,000 or 30,000 men to the Army was impossible, because the country could not stand the burden. We had not in any way adapted the Army to our policy, and in India we had enormously increased our responsibilities without increasing our strength, thus committing great political errors, which caused the Mutiny. Such have been the faults of politicians, moved by considerations of party advantage and forgetful of the welfare of the State, and thus has enormous outlay been caused, where a steady sufficient outlay would have sufficed. If expenditure be improperly reduced now, the day of reckoning, perhaps of disaster, and of much larger expenditure, will inevitably come later on. The Army on all occasions of unwise retrenchment has had to be saved by the soldier. Mr. Haldane cannot take his pattern in the matter of economy from Mr. Cardwell, because the reductions of that time were due to the larger measure in which the colonies were preparing themselves to undertake their own defence.

We had great hopes that the committee of Imperial Defence would enable , the Government to accomplish the nice business of adjusting military means to the ends in view, and we have not lost hope, though the test, it seems to us, will be supplied when Mr. Haldane makes his promised statement in July. Whatever may be the other purposes for which the Army may be employed, he may advisedly take the requirements of India as the standard. There we have gone on adding vastly to our dominions and millions to our population without ever doing anything to meet the larger responsibilities. The establishment of British Regular troops in India this year is 75,031; the Committee of 1859 fixed its proper strength at about 80,000, so that even upon the requirements of nearly half a century ago, we are now some 5,000 men short of the proper number. But compare the India of pre-Mutiny days with the India of the present time. Then the area of British territory was 776,000 square miles; it is now about a million square miles, being an increase of about one-quarter, while the population has grown by something like one-third. At the same time the population of the Native States has increased enormously, and we have added vast tracts of country and millions of people to the territory we have under control. We have strengthened our obligations to defend Afghanistan, and we foresee the approach of a great military power on the northern frontier and through Persia, indicated by the strategic railways that have been made and are contemplated. Can it then be pretended for a single moment that any case has been made ont for military reduction? The answer must be an unqualified negative. The need is rather for an increase than a decrease. ("Army and Navy Gazette.”)

div.head: NEW TUG FOR THE EGYPTIAN GOVERNMENT.
div.p: Messrs. Wm. Simons and Co., Ltd., Renfrew, launched from their works on Monday week a powerful screw tug, which they have built to the order the Egyptian Government, and which will be employed in connection with the harbour improvements at Alexandria. This vessel, which is designated "No. 10," is fitted with all the most modern equiment for tug steamers, and is fitted with one set of compound surface condensing engines supplied with steam from a Scotch type of boiler constructed for 120 lbs. per square inch. Built to the full British Admiralty requirements under the direction of Colonel Ruban, Director of Works, Admiralty, "No. 10," was launched complete with steam up and ready for trials. Lieutenant John F. James and Engineer Commander W.D. Chope have acted as resident Admiralty overseers over hull, engines, and boilers respectively.

div.head: FIRE IN HARBOUR.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE "EGYPTIAN GAZETTE."
div.p: Dear Sir, - In reference to the acccount of the fire in the harbour given in yesterday's issue of your paper we beg to state it is quite erroneous and utterly misleading.
The true facts of the case were as follows:
The fire on the above steamer was successfully extinguished by the sole efforts of the officers and crew, and no assistance whatever was rendered by anone apart from the persons mentioned.

In reference to the discharging of the cases of acid from ship's deck into lighters, said to have been done by Yousbashi Watt, there being only 20 cases, this also is erroneous, as the officers were responsible an carried out their particular work.
There is no desire on our part to take undue credit for what was not accomplished as some one wished to do, we merely wish to see fair-play.
Might we also call attention to the plucky performance of Ahmed Halil, who was solely instrumental in saving the life of one of the ship's company.
Apologising for encroching on your valuable time and space and hoping to see this account in an early edition of your paper,-We beg to remain, etc.
MASTER, OFFICERS, & CREW,
S.S. CITY OF DUNDEE
div.byline: [In justice to our courrespondents we feel compelled to insert the above letter. We would, however; add that the information we published in regard to the fire was derived from a thoroughly trustworthy source. Ep. E.G.

div.head: MURDER OF AN OMDEH
FOUND DEAD IN A FIELD.
(From our Special Correspondent.)
div.p: The Omdeh of Kafr el Arab, of Queens, in the Menoufieh Moudirieh, was found dead in a field this morning. No arrests have yet been made, but the police believe they are in possession of a clue to the murderer.

div.head: LOCAL AND GENERAL.
Prince Mohamed Ibrahim
div.p: T.H. Prince and Princess Mohamed Ibrahim arrived at Alexandria today from Marseilles by the French Packet.

div.head: Settlement in Egyptian Securities.
div.p: Wednesday, July 4th, has been fixed by the committee of the London Stock Exchange as a special settling day in Nile Valley; (New) Company, Ltd.—216,765 shares of £1 each, 18s. paid, Nos. 1 to 216,765; and July 5th as a special settling day in Agricultural Bank of Egypt—Scrip certificates to bearer (fully and partly paid) for £1,570,000 sterling 3 1/2 per cent. guaranteed bonds.

div.head: The Plague.
div.p: During the week ending June 24, three, cases of plague were reported throughout Egypt, two at Alexandria and one at Bibeh, Beni Souef. Between January 1 and June 24 of the current year 359 cases of plague were reported, against 103 and 647 in the corresponding periods of 1905 and 1904 respectively. One death occurred last week, one patient recovered, and eleven remained under treatment.

div.head: New Arabic Daily.
div.p: We hear that the new Arabic daily "Al Minbar" (“The Tribune”) will appear on July 1 under the editorship of Mr. Hafiz Awad and Mr. Mob. Massoud, who have already won their journalistic spurs on "Al Moayad.” We hope that their venture will be successful. Mr. Hafiz-Awad is a young journalist of broad views, who has proved himself consistently courteous and fair-minded in attack and defence, and has always shown remarkable literary ability.

div.head: Prince Aziz's New Yacht.
div.p: The yacht recently purchased at Southampton by Captain R.T. Phillips on behalf of H.H. Prince Aziz arrived at Alexandria on Sunday night from Falmouth-, after a pleasant voyage which last 12 1/2 days, in charge of Captain Phillips. The Cuhona, as the yacht is named, is said to be one of the best fitted vessels of the kind afloat, and is of 498 tons measurement. Prince Aziz came down from Cairo on Sunday night and went on board his new yacht, with which, we believe, his Highness is very pleased.

div.head: Ramleh's New Hotel.
div.p: The latest addition to the hotel accommodation of Alexandria, the New Victoria Hotel at Halt No. 9, Ramleh , is now open to receive visitors, who will find the new hotel replete with every modern comfort. Splendidly situated in an open position near the sea, opposite the telephone exchange, the New Victoria should attract a large clientèle in search of healthy surroundings. We shall have more to say as regards the furnishing of the hotel after the formal inauguration, which is to take place shortly, but we may just mention that the large dining room is one of the features of the building, which has been specially constructed for the purposes of an hotel.

div.head: Legislative Council's Journal
div.p: Some 60 native notables assembled on Sunday at the residence of H.E. Mohamed Pacha Suleiman, member of the Legislative Council, and dealt with the scheme for founding a new daily. A subscription list was opened under the presidency of the Pacha, who himself subscribed a sum of L.E. 500. Omar Bey Sultan subscribed L.E. 600 ; Sheikh Abdel-Rahim El Damerdaab, L.E. 500; and the others subscribed sums of L.B. 300, L.E. 200, L.B. 100, or L.B. 50 each. Abd El Hamid Bey El Logoufi was appointed treasurer to the company. It was decided that rules governing the scheme be read, before the subscribers, on the 23rd prox., when the subscriptions will be paid in.

div.head: Egyptians Hotels Company.
div.p: The accounts for the year ended April 30 show a profit of £27,093, after setting aside £5,889 for the redemption of Debentures. The directors declare a dividend of 17 1/2 per cent, on the Ordinary shares, leaving £1,413 to be carried forward. The directors in March 1905 entered into a contract with Mr. Charles Baehler to give him an option to purchase the balance of the surplus lands of the Ghezireh Estate for £10,000. Mr. Baehler voluntarily gave up this option, and subsequently sold the land for the benefit of the company for £220,000. The directors have' received £100,000 on account, less a commission in the transaction of £5,000; the balance (£120,000) is payable within ten years, without interest. The directors have reason to anticipate that this balance will be paid to the company long before the expiration of the ten years stipulated for.

div.head: THE DENISHWAI AFFAIR
div.p: Midnight.

So many were the details which were given by the witnesses called before the special tribunal today that when the Court rose at seven o’clock I could not complete the translation of my notes before the last post left and therefore, as you know, telegraphed you the remaining evidence. In case any mistake should have arisen from telegraphic transmission I will not write what I have wired and in greater detail. In my written account I reached the point where Lieutenant Smithwick deposed to all the officers, after they had been pulled from their carriage and himself dragged off his horse, running towards the camp.

Lieutenant Smithwick then said that after they had ran a short distance he turned round and saw that Major Pine-Coffin had been thrown to the ground, where he was held face downwards by a native who was on the top of him. Witness returned and pulled the man off and from among the prisoners he recognised No. 24 as this man. He could not say whether the man had a stick at that moment, but he certainly had one immediately afterwards and for the rest of the time. Major Pine-Coffin then shouted to Captain Bull to run to the camp and this he did in company with Captain Bostock, the two getting well ahead. Witness saw Captain Bull struck twice before this; once on the side and the other time on the back of the head with what he supposed was half a brick. Captain Bull, who staggered and appeared dazed, was bleeding profusely. Just as witness pulled the man off Major Pine-Coffin he was himself struck between the eyes by half a brick and then on the back of the neck by a nabout. The fellaheen then commenced to drag them back towards the village. They were thrown to the ground, and the natives then beat them, kicked them in the stomach, and generally maltreated them to make them get up again. Witness saw Major Pine-Coffin struck severely on both arms and said that he could identify the man who struck him on the right arm, but not the one who dealt the blow on the left. He then identified prisoner No. 23. He also recognised No. 14 as having had a stick in his hand and No. 25 as having been very violent and having thrown clods of mud, and bricks, and having used his stick. Witness lost consciousness. He recollected being taken to see the wounded woman and that two men made signs of cutting their throats, one of whom carried a hoe. He believed prisoner No. 26 to be this man. Before being taken to see the woman witness was separated from Major Pine-Coffin and Lieut. Porter and was thrown to the ground and beaten severely. When he was taken to the other two officers be found them sitting on a tibn floor and heaps of tibn were placed round them by boys, while Lieut. Porter remarked that they were going to be burnt. He next remembered lying under a tree and one fellah brought him water. This man was one of a ring who gathered round them and tried to keep the mob away. He remembered meeting the troops on their way to the place to where all this had taken place and heard either Major Pine-Coffin or Lieut. Porter—he could not say which—call to them to return to camp. He recognized prisoner No. 9 and believed him to have been friendly to them.

div.head: Cross-Examination.
div.p: On cross-examination witness stated that when they arrived at the ground for shooting he saw Major Pine-Coffin met by a man, hwom he identified as prisoner No. 11. Witness was riding and was by himself. When he went over to join Major Pine-Coffin he did not see any fire or smoke. When he went to join the other party it took from five to six minutes to get there, as far as he could tell. He lost his watch and his cigarette case, the latter being returned to him at the conclusion of the attack by an old man. The man who tok his watch had a short black beard, and either prisoner No. 13 or 51 might be he.

The Court then adjourned for a quarter of an hour, and on their return Lieut. Smithwick was questioned further. His gun was not returned to him and he identified one of the two guns placed before the tribunal as his. Mohamed Bey Youssef asked if the woman was wounded by the discharge of Lieut. Porter's gun. Witness said he heard so, but did not see it happen. He did not know that other persons were wounded. Ibrahim Bey Helbawi asked what would happen if a gun went off and there was a person three yards away. Witness said that for such a distance the charge would go like a bullet.

div.head: Captain Bostock's Evidence.
div.p: Captain Bostock was then called and said that he was on the S.E. side of the agricultural road with Lieut. Porter, who was about 100 yards away from him. Roughly speaking, he was about 100 yards from the nearest tibn and probably more than 300 yards from the village. Witness and Lt. Porter commenced shooting at once. No one cautioned them and he noticed no people as he went along the agricultural road.

After firing nine shots he noticed that people were collecting round him and he asked them to stand back, but as they did not do this he went backwarads himself in order to get more space. He found his way, barred and the people hindered him. Then a fire broke out, but only lasted about two minutes. The people then began to lay hands on himself and on his gun, and Lieut. Porter came towards him, but being also surrounded by people was not able to get nearer than ten or fifteen yards away from him. They then tried to get to the carriage, offering the crowd bakshish in the hope of pacifying the, but without avail. When he was struggling for his gun he felt someone rifle his pockets and he lost his watch, money, and cartridge bag. He was hit across the nose by a nabout. Major Pine-Coffin then arrived and tried to help them to get away and, as they were going along the road, they were beaten all the way. He could identify none of the prisoners as having done any special thing, but recognissed several as having formal part of the mob. He saw Captain Bull struck by a clod of earth and he was bleeding from the wound, but as he was some way from him he could not see his exact condition. The officers get into the carriage, but were dragged out again and beaten severely. They tried to get away and he saw Major Pine-Coffin thrown to the ground but could not say who threw him. When Major Pine-Coffin got up again witness took the lead, but on turning round saw the others surrounded. He noticed, however, that he had a clear road in front of him and ran towards the camp for help. When he had run about two miles he saw Captain Bull and shouted to ask him how he was getting on and received the answer "All right." Captain Bull told him to go to the police station on the left. He was not near enough to Captain Bull to see to what extent he was injured but he had seen him before injured and bleeding.
At this point Ahmed Bey Loutfi asked if witness could say why the people closed round him. Witness said he did not know, but that it was before the fire broke out.

div.head: Captain Bull's Death.
div.p: After returning from the camp witness saw Captain Bull lying in the shade in charge of the sergeant-major and he made a hasty examination. He noticed that he had a severe wound over the right temple and three or four blows on the head and was unconscious, so he took him to the camp as quickly as possible. He made a superficial post-mortem examination, and came to the conclusion that death was due to concussion of the brain and sun-stroke.

Ibrahim Bey Helbawi asked witness if he could say what length of time elapsed between them leaving the carriage to shoot and returning to it. Witness thought it woul dbe from three-quarters to one hour.

Dr. Nolan was called next and it was remarked that in his report of the autopsy which he held on the body of Captain Bull he stated that the wounds were caused by violent blows from some blunt instrument, but that this was not the direct cause of death. Dr. Nolan said that death was immediately due to heat apoplexy. Captain Bostock's evidence was not incompatible with witness's report and after hearing the evidence he was of the opinion that death was due to heat apoplexy which was aggravated by the concussion of the brain caused by the blows.
The Court then adjourned to meet again at half past eight tomorrow morning.

div.head: YESTERDAY'S HEARING.
div.p: It was shortly after half past eight when the tribunal commenced this morning's sitting.

Lieut. Porter was the first witness called, and, having been sworn, deposed that he went out pigeon shooting with Major Pine-Coffin, Capt. Bull, Capt. Bostock, and Lieut. Smithwick on the 13th inst. near the village of Denishwai. Witness went to the S.E. side of the agricultural road with Major Pine Coffin and indicated on a plan shown to him the position which he took up. He was between 200 and 300 yards from the village and about 150 yards from the nearest tibn floor. He had fired about half-a-dozen shots before he noticed any people or was interfered with. When he had shot four he saw that a crowd was collecting round Capt. Bostock and that he was being molested. As he went towards him he saw a fire break out in the tibn floor and he next noticed that about fifty people were rushing down from the village and surrounding them.

div.head: Gun Seized.
div.p: Witness did not see if the fire was put out. Several people sezied hold of his gun, which he tried to unload, but being unable to do so, owing to the interference, he put it at "safety." The gun went off almost immediately after it was taken from hiim. The crowd surged back, and he saw a woman lying on the gorund, but no other persons. After the gun had gone off he saw Major Pine-Coffin coming towards him that he thought someone had been hurt. Major Pine-Coffin took witness's arm, pretending to arrest him, and on meeting Lieut. Smithwick witness told him to take his other arm.

Up to that time he had not been struck, but had been pulled about, his clothes had been torn, and his cartridge bag taken from him. When they reached the carriages, Lieut. Porter got into one with Major Pine-Coffin and Capt. Bull and Capt. Bostock into the other, Lieut. Smithwick mounting his horse. Bricks were thrown at them, and they were afterwards pulled out of the carriages and beaten with sticks. They all commenced to run down the road. Witness saw Capt. Bull stagger as if he had been struck and he noticed that he was bleeding profusely from a wound in the region of the right eye. Major Pine-Coffin fell to the ground and Capt. Bull and Capt. Bostockstopped.

div.head: Jumped on his Stomach.
div.p: Witness saw that Capt. Bull was dazed and did not appear to know what he was doing. Lieut. Smithwick was with Major Pine-Coffin and as he was going to their help he was struck with a nabout by prisoner No. 14, who then ran to Major Pine-Coffin and jumped on his stomach with both feet. Major Pine-Coffin, Lieut. Smithwick, and witness were surrounded by fellaheen who started to drag them back to the village, and of these men he identified from among the accused thirteen, No. 25 said witness was carrying a hoe and when they were taken to see the wounded woman he made signs of cutting their throats. No. 9 resembled the omdeh's son, but witness could not say that he actually was his son. No. 14, said witness eventually robbed him of his gold match-box, silver chain and keys, cigar-case, pipe and tobacco pouch, whistle and corkscrew, which had not been returned. He gave his purse to the guide. They were first taken to the scene of the fire and made to sit down, when he thoguht they were going to be burnt. In about five minutes, they were taken to see the wounded woman, when No. 25 made signs of cutting their throats, and made them sit down near her.

div.head: Saved!
div.p: About this time a party of villagers formed a ring round them with a view to their protection and they were taken by these men to a mound a short distance away and the mob was held back. They were given water and in about half-an-hour, when Major Pine-Coffin and Lieut. Smithwick had sufficiently recovered, they were taken back to their carriages. They met a patrol of Mounted Infantry about a mile and a half down the road. Just before they finally left for the camp two mounted native police arrived and he thought that they asked them what they had lost. Witness thought the crowd was hostile from the moment it arrived, there being no children in it.

div.head: Carriage Driver's Deposition.
div.p: Abdel Aad Saat, the driver of one of the carriages, was next called and deposed to having received a telephonic message at El Wat to take carriages to Seraina market, where they would meet officers who were going shooting. This he did and two of the officers got into the carriage which he was driving and two into the other, while one officer went on horseback. When they arrived at the village of Denishwaithe onbashi of police who accompanied them, went into the village and the officers met an old man, whom he identified as prisoner No. 11. This man asked them if they were going to shoot pigeons. Witness recognized prisoner No. 16, prisoner No. 20, prisoner No. 35, prisoner No. 38, and prisoner No. 44 as having formed part of the crowd of fellaheen and said that he saw prisoner No. 20 dragging the officers along and beating them with nabouts.

The next witness was Mohamed Abd el Aad, driver of the second carriage. He deposed to seeing people strike the officers when they returned to the carriages, but only recognized prisoner No. 24 as having been present. He stated that he coul dnot drive away as the crowd would not allow him to, and that they took his whip from him.

Ibrahim Moussa, general messenger to the village, said that he went with the carriages from El Wat to Sersina, where they met the officers and then drove to Denishwai. On their arrival at Denishwai the officers told the onbashi of police to fetch the omdeh and the sheikh el ghaffir. They were met by a white bearded man, whom witness identifed as prisoner No. 11. This man, according to witness, told the officers not to shoot as there had been trouble over them doing so last year and the year before. If they shot they must do so on their own responsibility.

div.head: Subsequent Enquiries.
div.p: After the examination of this witness the Court adjourned for an interval of twenty minutes and on its return Abmed Bey Helbawi was called. Witness stated that on the 16th inst. he was sent for by the Moudir of Menoufieh, who related to him the incidents of the occurrence at Denishwai and instructed him to make enquiries and, if possible, to recover the guns. On the following day witness was informed by prisoner No. 2, whom he assured that he would come to no harm if he gave information, that guns were to be found in the house of prisoner No. 48 (Mohamed Darous Azwan). Witness did not believe his informant, but went to No. 40's house, where he found a woman sitting in the courtyard. He began to dig at the spot where the woman was seated and found two guns buried under the earth. Another person told him that there was a gun in the house of Said Mokattam, but on searching the house he found no gun, though he discovered on the roof a bag of cartridges. From the enquiries which he had made he stated that prisoners Nos. 48, 2, 11, and 19 were the ringleaders of the mob. When witness arrived at the omdeh's house, after being summoned there, he found a crowd of people whom he addressed, asking them to give him and information they could or to give up any of the missing things which were in their possession, and he told them that if they wished they could place the things at a certain spot just outside the village which he indicated and he would, then, not see who put them there. On Saturday he searched the sakkias and found nothing in the first one but in the second he discovered a gun.

div.head: Interruptions in Court.
div.p: Whilst this witness was giving evidence several of the accused interrupted him frequently, and this continued for some time. The Court threatened to sent them out if they did not stop interrupting witnesses and subsequently three of the greatest offenders were sent away. The evidence, too, given by the fellaheen was almost impossible to follow and the interpretations given by the translator were almost equally incomprehensible, chiefly owing to his being nearly inaudible.

Mohamed Omar Zaid was called and said that as he was going along the agricultural road he saw that there was trouble. He saw prisoner No. 19 (Mohamed Abd el Nebi) seize one of the officers' guns and he also saw No. 2 (Mohamed Dokran) either striking or catching hold of the officers, whereupon Mohamed Dokran ran interrupted loudly denying his statements and saying that witness bore enmity against him, and No. 48, whom witness said he saw taking the guns from the officers also asserted that this was the case. Witness identified Nos. 2, 48, 58, and 19 as active participators in the attack, and shortly afterwards No. 19 was taken out of Court for continued interruptions.

The next witness caled was Mohamed esh Shedli, who said that Mohamed Abd el Nebi, Mohamed Dokran, Hassan Magfous, and Ahmed Mohamed Salim took part in the attack. He saw Mohamed Abdel Nebi seize hold of one of the officers.
Ali Magfous, next witness, stated Major Porter's gun went off while the people were trying to seize it, and that when the other officers came up they fired three shots.

Omar Zaid, the omdeh's wakil, gave the names of fifteen men whom he saw among the hostile crowd, throwing stones and striking the officers with nabouts. He saw one officer hit across the eyes, another on the arm, and one thrown to the ground. He said that prisoner No. 48 had a stick in his hand, but did not see him holding a gun.
Fathalla Shedli, the omdeh's son, named fourteen men as having taken part in the attack, but could not say any of them were using sticks.

div.head: Ghaffirs Examined
div.p: After this witness had left the Court the ghaffirs, Ahmed Ali Shedli, Mohamed esh Shereef, Mohamed Shahata Allal, Ahmed Shahata Ghali, Ali Khalil, and Zian el Zazon were called in the order named and all gave evidence much to the same effect, naming several of those who were among the crowd.

The Court rose at one o'clock and on reassembling at four o'clock the onbashi of the police, hwo accompanied the officers, Ahmed Hassan Zazouk, was cross-questioned. He said that on arriving at Denishwai he was sent on to the omdeh's house and, on finding that he was away, asked for the wakil. He stated that when the people seized Lieut. Porter's gun he got hold of it to try to prevent them taking it away.

Lieut. Porter was reclled and said that he did not recognize the man. He had not got hold of his gun when the people seized it and when the fire broke out among the tibn he saw the onbashi of police about fifty yards away, and the latter made no attempt to reach him.
Several witnesses were called after this, including the mulahiz of police and the telephone clerk, but the evidence was of no great importance.

div.head: Address for Prosecution
div.p: The president of the tribunal, after the examination of these witnesses, stated that the Court would rise for half-an-hour, and when it reassembled Maitre Ibrahim Bey Helbawi, counsel for the prosecution, commenced his address. Counsel remarked first of all that every praise was due to the Army of Occupation during their stay in Egypt. "We must acknowledge," he said, "that England possesses the finest standing army in the world." Since the occurrences of the time of Arabi Pacha no such incident had occurred. Continuing, officers said that we now heard of English officers being severely treated and generally maltreated with no evident provocation.

He then related the main facts of the case, starting from the warning received by the district on the 10th inst. of the visit of the troops, numbering some 150, and requiring every facility for them. Counsel spoke for more than half an hour, dealing with the facts of the case, when the Court rose and at its resumed sitting tomorrow morning, he will continue his speech.

div.head: PROCEEDINGS TODAY.
div.p: Counsel for the prosecution continued his speech today enlarging on the savagery of the people and their murderous intentions towards the British officers. Four natives were wounded but only after Lieut. Porter's gun had been snatched from his hands and had exploded, as was shown by the position and nature of their wounds. The onbashi of police had been guilty of neglect of duty in going to lunch with a friend instead of going straight to the house of the omdeh and informing him of the arrival of the party. All the facts of the case showed that the officers were absolutely blameless.
Chibin el Kom, Tuesday, 10.46 a.m.

Counsel denounced Mohamed Mahfouz (prisoner No. 11) as the ringleader of the attack and as premeditating murder. Ahmed Sisi (No. 13), Youssef Hassan Salim (No. 14), Mohamed Abdelnebi (No. 19), Said Isssa Salim (No. 25), and Mohamed Darweesh Zahran (No. 48) were dencounced as other leaders.

div.head: "INTENTIONAL MURDER."
COUNSEL FOR PROSECUTION'S CONCLUSION.
div.p: Counsel for the prosecution concluded his speech, which lasted three hours and a quarter, by urging the execution of all the accused named in my previous telegram on the charge of intentional murder.

div.head: QUESTION IN PARLIAMENT.
div.p: In the House of Commons last week, Mr. Dillon (Mayo, E) asked the SEcretary of State for Foreign Affairs whether he could give any information as to the cause of the recent affray between Egyptians and British officers; whether the British officers were in uniform and were engaged in the performance of any military duty at the time; by what tribunal it was proposed to try the Egyptians concerned in the disturbance; and whether the trial would take place in public.

Sir. E. Grey.- The information which we have received hitherto states that during a march of mounted infantry from Cairo to Alexandria, five British officers were attacked by natives whilst shooting pigeons in a village near Tantah. One officer has died from the effects of the inuries he received, and two others are badly injured. The actual cause of the attack has not yet been ascertained, and it is not known whether the officers were at the time in uniform. The matter will be dealt with under a Khedivial decree of February 25, 1895, which institutes a special tribunal to deal with crimes of violence against officers and men of the Army of Occupation. The meetings of the tribunal will be held in public. The facts of the case cannot be thoroughly known until the judicial inquiry has taken place.

Mr. Dillon asked whether the right hon. gentlemen proposed to allow these Egyptians to be sent before the special tribunal before it had been proved that the officers were in uniform and were engaged in the performance of military duties.

Sir. E. Grey.- That is a point on which we have not yet received full information. We cannot tell without inquiry how far that point would affect the question of the tribunal before which the case should come.
Mr. Dillon.- Will the right hon. gentlement direct the attention of the Egyptian authorities to that point?
Sir. E. Grey.- We are expecting more information. I will bear that point in mind.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE IN STAMBOUL.
div.p: On this day of his arrival al Constantinople, a great banquet was given at Yildiz in honour of the Khedive, followed by an audience, his Highness afterwards proceeding to Bebel, the residence of his mother.
Our correspondent at Constantinople says that amongst other diplomatists who called on his Highness were the Persian Ambassador and the Greek Minister.

div.head: TRIPOLI.
div.p: Our Constantinople correspondent announces it to be the intention of the Turkish Government to occupy the Osses of Bilma, Barrows, and Jalo. The occupaion of the Gulf of Soloum is also under contemplation. The Porte officially denies these rumours.

div.head: FIRE AT KENEH PRISON.
div.p: A fire broke out here last night at the new prison. Thanks to the good work of our fire brigade it was extinguished in two hours. The sub moudir and local officials, with Mr. Warner, inspector of the Agricultural Bank, merited the thanks of the town by their great energy and activity.
The damages are estimated at L.E. 400.

div.head: MEDITERRANEAN SHIPPING COMBINE
div.p: It is stated that the competiton which has existed between the companies trading from the Continent to the Mediterranean and Black Sea Ports is now to cease. A mutual understanding has been arrived at, and a new tariff drawn up, the scope and sphere of each line being clearly defined.
The companies which have joined the Conferene are:-
The Royal Netherlands S.S. Company.
Atlas Company, of Bremen.
German Levant Line.
Sphinx Line.
Prince Line.
Westcott and Laurance.
Wm. Johnson and Co., Limited.
Forenede Company, of Copenhagen, and
Romanian State Railways.

div.head: Bulletin de la Bourse
div.p: Le marché, quoique calme a donné lien à quelques affaires, spécialement en Tramways privilégiées et en Delta Light; les autres valeurs n’éprouvent aucun changement ou à peu près.
La National Bank et l’Agricole clôturent à leurs cours d’hier.
L’Egyptian Delta Light gagne 1/16 à 11 15/16.
Les Tramways d’Alexandrie avancent de 2 francs à 191, par contre les dividendes reculent de 1 francs à 357.
L’obligation Crédit Foncier ancienne est stationnaire à 326 1/2, la nouvelle hausse de O fr. 75 à 271 1/2.
La Banque d'Athènes fléchit de cinquante centimes à 154 1/2.
La Delta Land réactionne de 3/32 à 3 3/4.
Les Trust et les Estâtes sont inchangés.
Les Entreprises Urbaines clôturent à 6 2/8 en hausse de 5/16.
Le Comptoir financier est échangé à 6 3/32.
La Banque d'Orient est à 132 1/2.

div.head: Circulaire H. De Vries et Boutigny
NOTES ET CRITIQUE
div.p: A Londres, le Consolidé anglais, qui avait clôturé vendredi passé en baisse de 3/8 à 88 3/8, s’est relevé samedi à 88 3/4, son cours de jeudi dernier. L’Unifiée, qui avait gagné 1/8 vendredi à 105, a réactionné de 1/4 le lendemain à 104 3/4. La National Bank a perdu 1/8 vendredi à 25 5/8 et restée samedi invariée à ce prix. L'Agricole et la Daïra sont demeurées inchangées à 9 5/8 et 17 1/8. La Delta Light a avancé avant-hier de 1/4 à 12.
A Paris, Faction Crédit Foncier Egyptien a regagné samedi à 772 1 franc qu’elle avait perdu k la clôture de la veille. La Banque d'Athènes s'est maintenue à 154.
Ici, lé marohé des valeurs a été, ce matin, assez animé, assez actif, avec tendance générale plutôt ferme.

La National Bank, délaissée, a.clôturé à son cours précédent, soit 25 9/16. Très mouvementée, l’Agricole a avancé à 9 23/32 pour finir à 9 11/16. La Cassa di Soonto a réactionné à 214 l’action ancienne et 211 la nouvelle. Le Comptoir Financier s’est inscrit à 6 3/32 l’action ancienne et 5 15/16 la nouvelle. La Banque d’Abyssinie a été cotée 5 7/8.
L’action Crédit Foncier a été offerte à 771; les obligations à lots 1886 ont été recherchées à 326 1/2. La Daïra Sanieh s’est raffermie à 17 1/16-1/8.
La Nile Land a rétrogradé à 13 7/16.
L’action de capital Eaux du Caire a gagné 2 francs à 120; les Jouissances ont également passé de 259 à 261.
L'action Ciments a progressé à 69.
L'action privilégiée Tramways d’Alexandrie a perdu 4 francs à 188 et l’action de dividende 5 francs à 355.
L’action Allotment est restée à 3 1/4; la part de fondateur a baissé à 112.
L’Union Foncière a reculé à 6 1/4.
L’action Entreprises Immobilières et Travaux a été demandée à 4 1/32; la part de fondateur a avancé à 67, acheteurs.

Dans le groupe des Hôtels, les Nungovich ont été négligés à leur cours précédent. Toujours en bonne tenue, les Baehler ont débuté à 5 9/16 pour clôturer à 5 11/16. Les Upper Egypt ont gagné 1/16 à 4 7/16, ainsi que les National à 3 5/16.

Parmi les petites valeurs, les Delta Land ont faibli à 3 13/16-7/8. Les Hooker ont, par contre, progressé à 1 3/32, de même que les Markets à 26 sh. 9, les New Egyptian à 29 sh. 6, les Salt and Soda à 20 sh. 6, la Khédivial Mail à 31 sh. 3 et les Walker and Meimarachi à 0 23/32.

Il ressort d’un avis officiel publié par le Crédit Foncier Egyptien que le conseil d’administration de cette Société a décidé d’appeler le deuxième quart sur les actions, soit Frs. 125 par titre, en deux versements égaux à effectuer aux dates suivantes:
Frs. 62,50 du 1er au 6 Septembre 1906;
Frs. 62.50 du 2 au 8 Janvier 1907.

On annonce d'Alexandrie que l’assemblée générale ordinaire de la Splendid Hotels of Egypt Co., tenue vendredi passé, a approuvé les comptes et bilan de l’exercice 1905-1906. Sur la proposition du conseil d’administration, le bénéfice net de l’exploitation a é’é reporté à nouveau.

Les actions de la Compagnie Agricole du Nil ont été introduites le 26 Mai dernier au marché en banque de la Bourse de Paris. Le cours d’admission a été de Frs. 270 pour les titres de la première émission.

La Cour d’appel mixte a décidé que les exécutions de valeurs ordonnées par les tribunaux d’Alexandrie et de Mansourah seront désormais faites en Bourse par les soins de l’Association des courtiers en valeurs.
Carnet de l’actionnaire.

Les actionnaires de l’Artesian Boring and Prospecting Co. sont informés que les dividendes pour les deux exercices écoulés sont payables, à partir du 1er Juillet prochair, au siège de la Société au Caire, à raison de 6 sh. contre remise da Coupon No. I des actions 1 à 400 de la valeur nominale de £5.

div.head: ALEXANDRIA GENERAL PRODUCE ASSOCIATION
SECTION COTONNIERE
Questionnaire De Juin 1906.
div.byline: Priere de respondre avant le 4 Juillet en vous servant de la langue que vous preferez.
div.p: 1.- La temperature du mois de Juin a-telle ete favorable aux Cotonniers?
2. - Les culturees sont-elle retardees on plus avancees en comparaison de celles de l'annee passee, a cette epoque?
3. - Les Cotonniers sont-ils en bon etat ou ont-ils ete contraries par quelque circonstance? (et laquelle?)
4. - L'eau pour les irrigations est elle abondante? ou bien est-elle suffisante? ou bien est elle insuffisante?
5. - Les vers du Coton sont-ils apparus en Juin. Et ont-ils fait des degats.
6. - Avez-vous d'antres observations a faire sur la perspective de la nouvelle recolte, en general.

div.head: Municipalite d'Alexandrie
SERVICE DE RECETTES
div.p: La President de la Commission Municipale a l'honneur de prevenir Messieurs les propietaires d'immenbles batis que, en execution du Decret du 13 Mars 1884, les elections des membres appeles a former les Commisions d'evaluations et le Conseil de Revision, auront line de 10 b. du matin a 4 h. dur soir aux endroits et sux jours indiques ci spres, pour chaque kiem dans les formes etablies par lea reglements.

La duree du mandat des membres des Commissions d'evaluations et du Conseil de revision fixee a deux anneas par l'art 6 du Decret, commencera le ler Aout 1906 Nul ne peut etre electeur et n'est eligible que dans le quartier ou il est proprietaire. Chaque electeur doit elire douze proprietaries a son choix sans distinction de nationalite.
div.docAuthor: La President de la Commision, MOUSTAPHA IBADI

div.head: TO-DAY'S TELEGRAMS
DREYFUS REHABILITATED
div.p: The Public Prosecutor stated, with reference to the Dreyfus case, that he was convinoed of the innocence of M. Dreyfus, and that none of the charges against him would bear examination; he had committed neither crime nor misdemeanour. (Reuter)

The Procurator General, M. Baudoin , condsidering that the borderau is the work of the counter-spy Esterhazy, declares that Dreyfus and Esterhazy are innocent of any crime. Under these conditions the Court will quash the judgment without adjournment. (Havas)

div.head: GREECE AND ROUMANIA.
div.p: Thousands of Greeks made a demonstration against the Roumanian mail steamer Princess Mary, which was anchored at Mytilene. The Governor sent a patrol to disperse the demonstrators and arrested 19 of them. He apologized to the captain. (Reuter)

The Havas Agency states that M. Bourgeouis has expressed his wishes for a prompt agreement between Greece and Roumania, and denies the contrary language attributed to him by a Bucharest newspaper. (Havas)

div.head: THE DUMA.
div.p: At another stormy sitting of the Duma, the deputies, amid thunders of cheering, declared that the Government was corrupt and impoverished the people, putting into its own pockets the money intended for the famine-stricken. The Minister of the Interior admitted that the struggle with famine was serious, but he refused to reply to the accusations. There was an outbreak of hisses, and cries of "Resign," and "Don't insult the Duma."

div.head: PRESIDENT ROOSEVELT'S DAUGHTER.
div.p: Mr. and Mrs. Longworth have arrived at Kiel in order to attend the regatta. They are being entertained by the Emperor William. (Reuter)

div.head: GERMAN EAST AFRICA.

div.head: TRAMCAR FATALITY AT HIGHGATE.
div.p: An electric tramcar dashed down Archway road, Highgate, and wrekced a hearse, motorbus, cab, van, several sops, and another tramcar. Many passengers jumped off, panic-stricken. altogether three persons were killed and 21 injured. (Reuter)

div.head: FOUR MONTHS IN SINAI.
div.p: (CONCLUDED)

In the interesting chapter on the mining expeditions of the ancients in his "Researches in Sinai,” noticed in yesterday's issue, Professor Petrie pays a tribute to the organising abilities of the Egyptians of all ages, in which abilities consists the secret of their power. The Egyptian of old time was nothing if not methodical in arranging the expeditions to the mines, and it is diverting to read of the variety and importance of the various recognised offices, from the chief, who was a “seal-bearer of the gods," "chief in the department of the interior," and “chief of the land of the North,” down to the "guards of the store house,” and tho "chief of the boats." Every department of work was fully provided for and each department recognised its own responsibilities. On one occasion a “chief physician" was mentioned as accompanying the party. It is evident that in the earlier times the armed forces were called upon to assist in the operations, as, during the reign of Amenembat II, reference is made to 734 soldiers being present.

The arrangement for the expedition commenced in December and continued until the commencement of the hot season, when the homeward journey was begun with the bags containing the gifts of the "Mistress of Turquoise."
The expedition was recorded on a great stele of the local sandstone, all the staff being usually mentioned, the chief of the party, of course, receiving great prominence.
Much information is given us respecting the monuments of the Kings and private individuals of note, and to the student this is invaluable.

Theologians will find the author’s views on the wanderings of the Israelites of engrossing interest. His careful consideration of all the circumstances, added to his knowledge of the topography of the country, will win for him the sympathetic attention of even those who are unable to accept all his conclusions. In dealing with this question, he finds, after a careful study of the diverse characteristics of the Jewish race and thei, literature, that "we cannot accept all the conclusions drawn from the documents, or the introduction of non-natural causes as setting à priori bounds to archaeological argument.”

He is of the opinion that the traditional identification of the region of Sinai must be accepted; that the itinerary during the three days’ journey into the wilderness was from Suez to Wady Gharandel. "It seems clear that the writer of these itineraries knew the road to Sinai well. The description exactly fits that road, and will not fit any other. He holds that the account of the journey does not tally with the theory that the march was eastward to the Gulf of Akabah, as there is no proof that the Midianites may Dot have occupied both sides of the gulf.

An interesting hypothesis to account for the apparent exaggeration of the numbers of the Israelites is placed before us by Professor Petrie. He suggests that the thousands referred to are families or tents, and the hundreds are the total inhabitants of these tents. In other words, the thousands are considered to have an origin entirely independent of the hundreds. A test of the traditional figures on this basis gives the total in the census taken before the wanderings of 5,550, and 5,730 at the close, as against the totals of 603.000 and 601.700 mentioned in the Book of Numbers. These figures tally with the present and ancient population of the country, with whom the Israelites fought on equal terms.
Professor Petrie thus conclude his admirably compiled and extremely interesting record:

“The work of this last season in Sinai has served to put in order the Egyptian inscriptions previously known there, and to fix their place and connections which were uncertain before. It has also uncovered many new inscriptions and the whole of these two or three inscriptions have been drawn full-size in facsimile, and many of them photographed. The publication of these will form the largest body of texts from any year’s work. The plan of the temple of Serabit was but vaguely known before. Many more walls have been found, and also the Shrine of the Kings ; and the whole is now fully planned and modelled, and the architectural details restored as far as possible. The district of Serabit has been planned for the first time, and the position and character of the temple includes the finest portrait known of Queen Thyi. The fuller records now obtained have enabled us to reconstruct the old Egyptian organisation of the expeditions, and the views that result from these studies regarding tho early Semitic ritual, restore what has hitherto been only a matter of conjecture. Never has a working party been more closely occupied with copying, and seldom have the resulting conclusions been of greater interest.”

The last four chapters of the book were prepared by Mr. C.T. Currelly, M.A., and refer to places Professor Petrie was not able to visit, including the journey from Tor to Maghareh and Mount Sinai. Some very useful statistics relating to the population of Sinai are also given by Mr. Currelly. Probably the most interesting feature of his contribution is the explanation of the manna, which he suggests was snow. This theory, however, does not enable us to account for the recorded statement that the Children of Israel were daily sustained by the manna. It is hardly likely that snowstorms would be so frequent, nor can snow by any manner of reasoning be considered food, and this obstacle Mr. Currelly admits. He adds: "If the story of manna does not reflect the startling effect produced upon the Hebrews by the sight of snow, the only other explanation that appeals to me is that the sotry itself is literally true."

Professor Petrie's work is well arranged, and the accompanying photographs and maps, of which there are 190, are remarkably good. The book takes its place as the most valuable pronouncement on Sinaitic research yet given to the world.
div.byline: "Researches in Sinai" by Professor Flinders Petrie. London: John Murray, Albemarle St. Price 21s.

div.head: SUEZ CANAL COMPANY.
div.p: The general meeting of the shareholders of the Suez Canal Company was held in Paris on Tuesday week. The report of the President, Prince Auguste d'Arenberg, begins by pointing out that, after the first few months of 1905, there was a slight diminution of traffic in the canal, causing a falling-off of some 2,100,100f. (£84,000) in the receipts. This state of things, however, may be considered as entirely satisfactory having regard to the remarkable and exceptional activity during 1904 following upon a series of years during which there was a steady advance in traffic through the canal. The board of directors propose, therefore, to maintain the figure of 141f. (£5 12s.9) for the dividend, and to set apart 3,000,000f. (£120,000) for the reserve fund. The total receipts for 1905 amount to 117,308,196f. (£4,692,324). and the expenses to 40,984,184f. (£1,639,364). During the year 1906, 4,116 ships, representing 13,134.105 tons, went through the canal. The average tonnage, which was stationary in 1904, rose in 1905 from 3,163 to 3,191 tons. Progressive increase in the average draught of the vessels going through the canal is one of the essential elements in the increase of receipts. In 1885 the average tonnage was 1,748 tons. The progress in twenty years has, therefore, been about 80 percent. Yet navigation in the canal is becoming safer every year, as is shown by the diminishing number of founderings. The company have just ordered a second tug boat, so as to do all in their power to avoid delay in going through the canal. The accident to the Chatham furnished an occasion for showing the great resources of the company and the loyalty of the staff. Work is now proceeding from kilomètre 61 to Suez for the widening of the canal by at least 15 mètres. Prince d’Arenberg gives other details of the activity in dredging in the construction of new basins, etc. During the opening months of 1906 traffic in the canal has been maintained at a very high level, due partially to the repatriation of Russian troops. This special movement still continues.

The Prince d'Arenberg, in his opening speech, referred to the stranding of the British vessel Chatham in the canal with a large quantity of dynamite on board, and the consequent hindrance to traffic extending over several weeks. He spoke in warm terms of the engineers and workmen who, at the risk of their lives, blew up the obstruction, and asked the shareholders to join In the congratulations of the Council of Administration. (Applause.) In conclusion, the Chairman insisted on the necessity of proceeding as rapidly as possible with the task of widening and deepening the canal. All the proposals of the board were unanimously adopted, and the outgoing directors were re elected. The report was read and passed without a single question being put. The British members of the Council of Administration present were Sir H. Austin Lee, Mr. H. T. Anstruther, General Ardagh, M. R. S. Donkin, Mr. F. Green., Mr. J. W. Hughes, and Lord Rathmore. Tbe Egyptian Government was represented by M. Emile Olivier. Vice-Admiral Humann, M. Stephene Derville (President of the Paris-Lyons-Mediterranean Railway), M. Andre Lebon (ex-Minister), and M. Bazin were elected to the board in place of members deceased.

div.head: THE BOUNDARY QUESTION.
div.p: ‘Al Mokattam” publishes a statement from its correspondent at El-Areesh to the effect that the inhabitants of Gaza and the neighbouring villages, who have been hoping that the boundary between the Turkish and Egyptian territories would be drawn to the east of their town, which would free them from Turkish rule, appear to be displeased with the new delimitation, which has not fulfilled their hopes.

The Turco-Egyptian officials, says our contemporary, arrived recently at a well called "El-Mayein,” S.E. of El-Areesh, and at a distance of three and a-half days’ march from that town. The Egyptian officials are expected to arrive at El-Areesh in the first week of July.

"Al Mokattam's" correspondent learns that many Jewish emigrants from Russia have come to Ramleh, near Gaza, where they are now residing, and that the Turkish authorities are profiting by assisting them to take possession of land in that district.

div.head: ARMY AND NAVY.
div.p: The sad death of Captain Seymour C. Bull, Inniskilling Dragoons, has been the almost sole topic in Service circles since the intelligence became known. Very much regret is expressed at his untimely end, and the wish that the perpetrators of the murderous assault will be brought to justice. In Dublin, Belfast, and Cork, where the unforutnate officer served successively prior to the embarkation of the regiment, he was very popular and his good record of service with the regiment, and his hearty manner and genial temperament under all circumstances, made him hosts of friends at every place he served. it was a sad end to a promising career.

Some changes are announced in the commissioned ranks of the Royal Dublin Fusiliers. Captain and Brevent Major E. Fetherstonbaugh, on absorption, is posted to the 1st Battalion at Alexandria, for where he will embark in due course; Major R. A. Rooth, on promotion, remains with the 2nd Batt. at buttevant, and Captain H.J. Kinsman has been transferred from the 1st Battalion to the 2nd Battalion. Major W. Bromilow, 2nd Battalion, has been selected from amongst the majors of the regiment for the appointment of second in command of the 1st Battalion, Alexandria, and further orders for his embarkation will be made. Major Bromilow received his first commission in the Dublins a little over 22 years ago. His selection for the appointment should in the ordinary course give him the command of a battalion before being caught up by the age rules. He got his company in 1893, and majority just at the close of the Boer war, in which he saw service from the autumn of 1901 till the end, including the operations on the Zululand Frontier, and the Transvaal (Queen's medal with four clasps) and the numerous minor affairs in which the 1st Battalion was engaged.

The Sergeants' Mess of the 1st Battalion Scots Guards, Aldershot, has just received from Colonel G.J. Cuthbert, late commanding the battalion, and now Assistand Adjutant General at Cairo, a very valuable and much-prized token of his regard in the shape of a notice board. It is covered with blue cloth, and set in a massive silver frame, surmounted by the regimental crest, and the date "April 24th, 1906" - the day on which he gave up command of the battalion to the regret of all ranks. On the frame are engraved the names of the members of the mess, and along the bottom the inscription: "Presented to the Sergeants' Mess, 1st Battalion Scots Guards, by Col. Cuthbert, in remembrance of happy days gone by." The gift has occasioned the greatest pleasure amongst the members of the mess. Their old commanding officer is not likely to be forgotten by those who had the privilege of serving under him.

Sergeant Young, 1st Battalion Royal Inniskilling Fusiliers, and Sergeant H.T. Foster, 1st Battalion Royal Berkshire Regiment; Sergeants J. Keenan and M. Lee, 2nd Battalion Royal Dublin Fusiliers, have passed at the School of Musketry, Hythe, and obtained the usual certificate.

A severe test of the capabilities of Mounted Infantry was made at Aldershot this week in a series of operations centred round the capture and retention of a hill. Sir John French, who is a firm believer in the value of the M.I., watched the phases of the fight with the greatest keenness and the French Military Attache was also an interested spectator.
Admiral Sir Lewis Beaumont will accompany the Prince of Wales to Norway

Captain Lionel G. Tufnell has been appointed to the command of the battleship Irresistible on the Mediterranean Station from the 20th inst. The new skipper of the battleship joins her with 36 years naval experience, as he entered the service as a cadet in July, 1870. He got his lieutenancy in 1881, was promoted commander in 1895, and a captain in June, 1901. Captain Tufnell is well known throughout the Service as the clever inventor of a system of instruction in signalling which obviates the necessity of using full sized flags. He was latterly employed in the command of the Astrae, which he recently brought home from the China Station.
